title: 106_hr243
content: The Act titled `Older and Disabled Americans Criminal Protection Act of 1998' includes provisions for background checks. The Act 'Older and Disabled Americans Criminal Protection Act of 1998' allows shared housing referral services to request background checks on applicants for participation in shared housing arrangements by submitting fingerprints and a written authorization to the Attorney General within 7 days. The Act 'Older and Disabled Americans Criminal Protection Act of 1998' permits shared housing referral services to request background checks on applicants by submitting fingerprints to the Attorney General, who will search FBI records and provide relevant information to authorized agencies for suitability determination. The Attorney General may charge a fee of up to $50 for shared housing referral services requesting background checks. A report on the number of requests and outcomes must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. CRIMINAL PENALTY. Whoever knowingly uses information obtained in violation of section 2(c) may be fined or imprisoned for up to 2 years. SEC. 4. ORGANIZATIONAL LIABILITY. A shared housing referral agency relying on information from the Attorney General is not liable for damages due to incomplete or inaccurate information. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines a 'shared housing arrangement' as a living situation where at least 2 unrelated individuals share a dwelling unit, with one being the owner or lessee and the other providing care or services in exchange for free or reduced occupancy. The Act defines a 'shared housing arrangement' as a living situation where at least 2 unrelated individuals share a dwelling unit, with one being the owner or lessee and the other providing care or services in exchange for free or reduced occupancy. A 'shared housing referral service' is a nonprofit organization that refers individuals or families for shared housing arrangements. A 'service provider resident' is the individual participating in the arrangement. The terms 'elderly person' and 'person with disabilities' have specific meanings as per the United States Housing Act of 1937. The Attorney General can create regulations for implementing the Act, covering information security, accuracy, audits, fees, and recordkeeping.
